questions.text: Which of the following tests is most appropriate for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Grattage Test is used to diagnose psoriasis, a condition characterized by scaly plaques on the skin. In this test, gentle scraping of the lesion leads to removal of scales in a characteristic manner, revealing a shiny, thin membrane (Auspitz sign) and pinpoint bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Nikolsky Test (Option A): Used to diagnose conditions like pemphigus vulgaris and toxic epidermal necrolysis. It involves applying lateral pressure to the skin, which causes the epidermis to slough off.

 

Asboe-Hansen Test (Option B): Also known as the bulla spread sign, it helps diagnose pemphigus vulgaris by checking if pressure on a blister spreads it to adjacent skin.


Tzanck Smear( Option D): Used to diagnose herpes infections by detecting multinucleated giant cells in skin lesions.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Impetigo

 

Explanation:

 

The lesion shown in the image has the following classic features:

  • Location: Perioral (around the mouth)

  • Appearance: Reddish base with overlying golden-yellow or honey-coloured crusts

  • Surface: Crusted, shallow erosions without deep ulceration or scarring

  • Distribution: Localised, possibly multiple lesions

  • No systemic symptoms: Usually mild or absent fever

These clinical features are hallmark signs of impetigo, especially the non-bullous type.

  • Impetigo is a highly contagious superficial bacterial skin infection, most common in children.

  • Causative organisms:

    • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)

    • Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A strep)

 

Chickenpox (Option B): 

  • It presents with a generalised vesicular rash on an erythematous base ("dew drop on a rose petal") in different stages of healing.

  • Typically starts on the trunk, not just around the mouth.

Herpes Simplex (Option C): 

  • It shows painful grouped vesicles, later forming ulcers or crusts.

  • Lesions recur and are often associated with burning or tingling sensations.

  • HSV lesions are clear vesicles, not honey-coloured crusts.

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option D):

  • It presents as small, dome-shaped, pearly papules with central umbilication.

  • Lesions are not crusted or erosive, and there is no honey-coloured appearance.

questions.text: Auspitz sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Psoriasis vulgaris

Explanation:

The Auspitz sign, characterized by the development of pinpoint bleeding in the areas where the lesion is scraped with a glass slide, is commonly associated with psoriasis vulgaris

While examining a patient’s psoriatic lesions during scraping with a blunt object such as the blunt edge of a glass slide, the following signs are seen:

Grattage Sign/ Cadle sign: Accentuation of scaling when the lesion is scraped with the blunt edge of a glass slide

                                                                          ↓

Berkeley’s membrane: Formation of a thin membrane on further scraping

                                                                          ↓

Auspitz sign: Formation of pin-point bleeding on scraping the Berkeley’s membrane in patients with psoriasis.

Another sign, "Sign of the last Hautchen" or "Sign of the Last Scale," refers to the presence of small, raised, erythematous papules that become visible after the last scale is removed from a psoriatic plaque, i.e., before the formation of Berkeley’s membrane.

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Isomorphic phenomenon

Explanation:

  • The above image depicts Pustular psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales.
  • Isomorphic phenomenon: The isomorphic phenomenon is the correct finding associated with the image. In individuals with psoriasis, new psoriatic lesions can appear at sites of skin trauma, such as scratches, cuts, or other forms of injury.

Koebner's Phenomenon

  • Psoriatic lesions develop along the lines of trauma.
  • Isomorphic response
  • All or none phenomenon

Category

Examples

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Psoriasis, Lichen planus, Vitiligo

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Warts, Molluscum

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

Darier disease, Erythema multiforme

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Pemphigus vulgaris, Lupus erythematosus

 

Incorrect Options:

Meyerson phenomenon (Option B): The Meyerson phenomenon refers to the development of psoriatic lesions after light tapping or pressure on a psoriatic plaque.

Gottron's papule (Option C): Gottron's papule appear as flat-topped, violaceous eruptions overlying the joints of the fingers and elbows.

Nikolsky's sign (Option D): Nikolsky's sign refers to the ability to induce blistering or detachment of the superficial skin layers by lateral pressure or rubbing (positive Nikolsky's sign). This sign is not relevant to plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not advise for a patient who is already diagnosed with chronic plaque psoriasis and has over 50% of their skin affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral steroids

Explanation:

  • In the case of a patient with chronic plaque psoriasis involving more than 50% of the skin, oral steroids are generally not recommended as a long-term treatment option due to the risk of severe rebound flares and pustular psoriasis upon withdrawal.

Reasons Why Oral Steroids Are Avoided

  1. Rebound Phenomenon
    • Sudden discontinuation can cause severe exacerbation of psoriasis, leading to erythroderma or pustular psoriasis (potentially life-threatening).
  2. Risk of Pustular Psoriasis
    • Systemic steroids can trigger generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP), characterized by widespread sterile pustules, fever, and systemic illness.
  3. Limited Long-Term Efficacy
    • While steroids provide short-term relief, they do not alter disease progression and often require higher doses over time, leading to dependency.

Preferred Long-Term Treatment Options

  • Biologics (e.g., IL-17, IL-23, TNF inhibitors)
  • Methotrexate, cyclosporine, or apremilast (for systemic therapy) (Option A and C)
  • Phototherapy (NB-UVB- Narrowband ultraviolet B) (Option B)
  • Topical therapies (vitamin D analogs, corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors) for localized disease

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who has lacy lesions in her mouth and genital area, while her proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • The combination of lacy lesions in the mouth and genital area, along with nail changes, strongly suggests lichen planus.

 

Lichen Planus:

Clinical Features

  • 6 P’s → Pruritic, Purple, Polygonal, Planar Papules & Plaques
  • Mucosal involvement → Wickham striae (reticular white lines)
  • Koebner phenomenon: This phenomenon refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin
  • Histology → Sawtooth infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction
  • Association → Hepatitis C

 

Treatment

Topical (First-line for mild cases)

  • Corticosteroids (Clobetasol, Betamethasone)
  • Calcineurin Inhibitors (Tacrolimus, Pimecrolimus) – for oral/genital LP
  • Antihistamines – for pruritus relief
  • Local anesthetics (Lidocaine gel) – for painful oral lesions

Intralesional (For hypertrophic LP)

  • Intralesional corticosteroids (Triamcinolone injections)

Systemic (For severe, widespread, or refractory cases)

  • Oral corticosteroids (Prednisolone)
  • Dapsone
  • Hydroxychloroquine (HCQS)
  • Azathioprine, Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF)

Phototherapy (For generalized LP, especially in children)

  • Narrow-band UVB (NBUVB) phototherapy

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (Option A):

  • Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) typically presents with scaly, red follicular plaques and islands of sparing near the axilla called islands of sparing
  • It histopathologically exhibits a distinctive checkerboard pattern marked by alternating areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.

Psoriasis (Option B):

  • Features silvery scales on erythematous plaques, commonly on extensor surfaces.
  • Nail changes include pitting, oil-drop sign, and onycholysis, but not pterygium formation.
  • Oral lesions are rare.

 

Pityriasis rosea (Option C):

  • Starts with a herald patch followed by oval, scaly lesions in a "Christmas tree" pattern.
  • No oral/genital lesions or nail involvement.

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions, as shown in the image below, and later developed arthritis also. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methotrexate

Explanation:

  • The patient has psoriasis (as indicated by the psoriatic plaque in the image) and later developed arthritis, suggesting psoriatic arthritis
  • The drug of choice used to treat Psoriatic arthritis is methotrexate
  • Methotrexate belongs to a class of drugs called disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARDs). It reduces inflammation and alleviates the symptoms of arthritis.

Treatment:

Medical:

  • NSAIDs
  • Immuno suppressive agents- methotrexate and TNF inhibitors
  • Local glucocorticoid injections
  • Physiotherapy

Surgery:

  • For unstable joints.
  • Arthrodesis procedure.

Incorrect Options:

PUVA (Option A):

  • PUVA does not work effectively in reducing the arthritic condition.
  • Methotrexate is preferred over PUVA for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis.

Steroids (Option B): Oral and topical corticosteroids can be used for short-term therapy but are not recommended for long-term use due to their many adverse effects.

Infliximab (Option D): Infliximab is preferred in moderate to severe cases of Psoriatic arthritis but is not the first drug of choice due to it being more expensive.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with an itchy skin rash. Physical examination reveals flat-topped, polygonal, purplish papules with fine white lines on the surface. The lesions are primarily located on the inner wrists and forearms, as well as on the lower back. The patient reports that he has been experiencing oral discomfort and noticed white, lacy patches on the inside of his cheeks. There is no family history of similar conditions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by pruritic, violaceous, flat-topped papules. It frequently affects the flexor surfaces of the wrists, forearms, lower back, and mucosal surfaces.

Lichen Planus:

Clinical Features

  • 6 P’s → Pruritic, Purple, Polygonal, Planar Papules & Plaques
  • Mucosal involvement → Wickham striae (reticular white lines)
  • Koebner phenomenon: This phenomenon refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin
  • Histology → Sawtooth infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction
  • Association → Hepatitis C

Treatment

Topical (First-line for mild cases)

  • Corticosteroids (Clobetasol, Betamethasone)
  • Calcineurin Inhibitors (Tacrolimus, Pimecrolimus) – for oral/genital LP
  • Antihistamines – for pruritus relief
  • Local anesthetics (Lidocaine gel) – for painful oral lesions

Intralesional (For hypertrophic LP)

  • Intralesional corticosteroids (Triamcinolone injections)

Systemic (For severe, widespread, or refractory cases)

  • Oral corticosteroids (Prednisolone)
  • Dapsone
  • Hydroxychloroquine (HCQS)
  • Azathioprine, Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF)

Phototherapy (For generalized LP, especially in children)

  • Narrow-band UVB (NBUVB) phototherapy

Incorrect Options:

Psoriasis (Option A):

  • Characterized by silvery-white scales on erythematous plaques, mostly on extensor surfaces.
  • Nail pitting and onycholysis are common.

Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis) (Option B):

  • Poorly demarcated, erythematous, weeping lesions with crusting and lichenification.
  • Typically affects flexural surfaces (e.g., antecubital, popliteal fossae).

Tinea Corporis (Option D):

  • Annular (ring-shaped) lesions with a central clearing and scaly border.
  • Fungal infection, confirmed by KOH preparation showing hyphae.

questions.text:
Please match the following types of scales with their corresponding lesions.

 


	
		
			
			Scales
			
			
			Lesions
			
		
		
			
			1. Collarette scales
			
			
			a. Pityriasis versicolour
			
		
		
			
			2. Silvery scales
			
			
			b.Pityriasis rosea
			
		
		
			
			3. Mica–like scales
			
			
			c.Psoriasis
			
		
		
			
			4. Branny scales
			
			
			d.Pityriasis lichenoides
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Each type of scale is associated with a characteristic dermatological condition:

  1. Collarette scales – Pityriasis rosea (1-b)
    • Fine, trailing collarette of scales surrounding oval, salmon-coloured plaques seen in pityriasis rosea.
    • Most prominent around the edges of herald patches.
  2. Silvery scales – Psoriasis (2-c)
    • Thick, silvery-white scales over erythematous plaques, classically seen in psoriasis.
    • Removal may lead to Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding).
  3. Mica-like scales – Pityriasis lichenoides (3-d)
    • Fine, adherent mica-like scales covering small, erythematous papules.
    • Seen in pityriasis lichenoides, a chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  4. Branny scales – Pityriasis versicolour (4-a)
    • Fine, powdery, branny scales seen in pityriasis versicolour, a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia.
    • Often reveals yellow-green fluorescence under Wood’s lamp.

Scales in Dermatology:

Scales are abnormal accumulations of keratinized cells on the skin surface and are characteristic of various dermatological conditions. They can vary in thickness, texture, and pattern based on the underlying disease.

Type of Scale

Description

Associated Disease

Key Clinical Features

Collarette scales

Thin, peripheral scales arranged in a collarette pattern, often seen in annular lesions.

Pityriasis rosea

Herald patch followed by a "Christmas tree" distribution of lesions.

Silvery scales

Thick, silvery-white, adherent scales that bleed upon removal (Auspitz sign).

Psoriasis

Well-demarcated erythematous plaques on extensor surfaces, scalp, and lower back.

Mica-like scales

Fine, thin, shiny scales resembling mica.

Pityriasis lichenoides

Chronic or recurrent papulosquamous eruptions.

Branny scales

Fine, powdery, furfuraceous (bran-like) scaling.

Pityriasis versicolor

Hypo- or hyperpigmented macules caused by Malassezia, commonly on the trunk.

questions.text: A patient presented with itchy lesions, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Lichen Planus

  • The image shows multiple violaceous, polygonal, pruritic papules predominantly on the lower extremities, which is characteristic of lichen planus.

  • The presence of Wickham striae (fine white reticulations) supports the diagnosis.

Lichen Planus

Feature

Lichen Planus

Etiology

Autoimmune, drug-induced (ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs), Hepatitis C association

Clinical Features

Purple, pruritic, polygonal, planar papules

Common Sites

Wrists, ankles, oral mucosa, nails

Koebner Phenomenon

Lesions at sites of trauma

Wickham Striae

Fine white lacy network over papules

Nail Changes

Longitudinal ridging, nail thinning

Treatment

Topical steroids, antihistamines, systemic therapy in severe cases

Scabies (Option A): Incorrect because scabies presents with burrows, interdigital involvement, and nocturnal itching.

Psoriasis (Option C): Incorrect because psoriasis has silvery scales on erythematous plaques, usually on extensor surfaces.

Warts (Option D): Incorrect because warts are hyperkeratotic papules caused by HPV, without pruritus or Wickham striae.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of both arms. Punctate pitting was noted on examining the nails. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Psoriasis

  • The patient presents with erythematous plaques with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces, which is classic for psoriasis.

  • Nail pitting is a characteristic feature of psoriatic nail involvement.

Psoriasis

Feature

Psoriasis

Common Sites

Extensor surfaces (elbows, knees), scalp, lower back

Lesion Type

Well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales

Koebner Phenomenon

Lesions appear at sites of trauma

Nail Changes

Pitting, onycholysis, oil-drop sign

Treatment

Topical steroids, vitamin D analogs, systemic biologics in severe cases

Signs in Psoriasis

Sign

Description

Candle-Grease Sign

Silvery-white, shiny scales appear on scraping.

Last Häutchen Sign

Thin transparent membrane seen after scale removal.

Auspitz Sign

Pinpoint bleeding after removing the last membrane.

Koebner Phenomenon

Psoriatic lesions appear at sites of trauma.

Woronoff Ring

Pale ring around healing psoriatic plaques.

Lichen planus (Option B): Incorrect because lichen planus presents with purple, pruritic, polygonal papules and Wickham striae, not silvery scales.

Eczema (Option C): Incorrect because eczema involves flexural surfaces and is associated with intense pruritus and weeping lesions.

Pityriasis rosea (Option D): Incorrect because it presents with a herald patch followed by a Christmas-tree distribution of lesions, not thick silvery scales.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with an asymptomatic Collarette scale as shown in the image below. Identify the pattern.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

Explanation:

The image depicts an asymptomatic Collarette scale. This presentation is characteristic of Pityriasis rosea, a common skin condition that often begins with a single, large, scaly plaque known as the "herald patch." The subsequent rash that follows often has a distinctive "Christmas tree pattern" on the trunk, which corresponds to the orientation of the lesions.

 

Wickham's striae - Lichen planus (Option B): Wickham's striae is a term used to describe the fine white lines or dots that are characteristic of Lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory condition. However, Lichen planus typically presents with polygonal, flat-topped papules rather than the described Collarette scale.

Christmas tree pattern - Lichen planus (Option C): Lichen planus is characterized by Wickham's striae, as mentioned above. However, the description of a Collarette scale is more indicative of Pityriasis rosea.

Woronoff ring - Seborrheic dermatitis (Option D): A Woronoff ring refers to a ring-shaped area of clearing or central healing within a skin lesion. It is not specifically associated with Seborrheic dermatitis. Seborrheic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous, scaly plaques in areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp and face.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with scaly lesions over the body, as shown in the Image below. No other associated symptoms are present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pityriasis Rosea

Explanation:

Pityriasis Rosea is a scaly red lesion that usually occurs on the trunk. They are scaly heralds patches and a collarette of scales can be seen. It usually presents 2-3 weeks after URTI and Gl infections.

Lichen planus (Option A): Presents as papulosquamous disorder which affects the skin, mucosa, hair, and nails. It is pruritic and it affects flexure surfaces.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option C): Usually seen as red itchy, scaly patches on the skin. Since in this case, it is asymptomatic it cannot be this option.

Atopic dermatitis (Option D): Atopic dermatitis is dry, itchy, and erythematous. It is not asymptomatic. Hence the incorrect choice.

questions.text: A child with a sore throat starts developing skin lesions as in the image below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Guttate psoriasis

Explanation:

  • The image given above is of Guttate psoriasis
  • It is commonly seen in children.
  • It is usually preceded by streptococcal infection
  • Small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk which gives raindrop-like appearance are seen
  • Treatment: Antibiotics (penicillin, amoxicillin)

Pustular Psoriasis (Option B): Pustular psoriasis (a type of unstable psoriasis) characterized by the presence of multiple sterile, non-infectious pus-filled blisters on erythematous skin, forming a characteristic 'Lakes of pus' appearance.

Erythrodermic Psoriasis (Option C): It is another variant of unstable psoriasis that presents with erythema and scales covering more than 90% of the body surface.

Inverse Psoriasis (Option D): Affects intertriginous areas (axilla, groin, inframammary folds) and presents with shiny, erythematous plaques without scaling, unlike guttate psoriasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with itchy, flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules on the inner wrists and flexors surfaces of the forearms. The lesions have a characteristic shiny surface and are arranged in a linear pattern. The patient denies any recent medication changes. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Topical steroids

Explanation:

  • The patient's itchy, flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules on the inner wrists and flexor surfaces of the forearms are characteristic of Lichen Planus (LP).

Lichen Planus:

Clinical Features

  • 6 P’s → Pruritic, Purple, Polygonal, Planar Papules & Plaques
  • Mucosal involvement → Wickham striae (reticular white lines)
  • Koebner phenomenon: This phenomenon refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin
  • Histology → Sawtooth infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction
  • Association → Hepatitis C

Treatment

Topical (First-line for mild cases)

  • Corticosteroids (Clobetasol, Betamethasone)
  • Calcineurin Inhibitors (Tacrolimus, Pimecrolimus) – for oral/genital LP
  • Antihistamines – for pruritus relief
  • Local anesthetics (Lidocaine gel) – for painful oral lesions

Intralesional (For hypertrophic LP)

  • Intralesional corticosteroids (Triamcinolone injections)

Systemic (For severe, widespread, or refractory cases)

  • Oral corticosteroids (Prednisolone)
  • Dapsone
  • Hydroxychloroquine (HCQS)
  • Azathioprine, Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF)

Phototherapy (For generalized LP, especially in children)

  • Narrow-band UVB (NBUVB) phototherapy

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with rashes with an orange hue on his body and thickened palms and soles. Based on the histological image given, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pityriasis rubra pilaris:

  • The patient’s presentation with orange-hued rashes, thickened palms and soles, and the histological findings (checkerboard pattern of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis) are characteristic of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP).

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D show a different histopathological pattern.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition using the histological image provided.
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Morphea

  • Biopsy from the indurative stage of morphea (localized scleroderma) is squared off at the edges, giving the appearance of box-shaped (or boxed dermis appearance)
  • This boxing of the dermis probably happens due to the marked sclerosis of collagen throughout the reticular dermis and extending to the septa of subcutaneous fat.
  • Morphea-lichen sclerosus overlap and scleredema can also similarly show squared off edges of biopsy specimen.

 

Incorrect Options

Option B - Lichen nitidus: Histology of lichen nitidus showing well-defined granuloma enclosed by rete pegs giving the appearance of "claw clutching a ball" 

Option C - Lichen planus:

  • The histological image is consistent with lichen planus, showing a dense band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermo-epidermal junction and saw-toothing of the rete ridges.

questions.text: Which of the following does not distinguish Psoriasis from other arthropathies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diarrhoea

Explanation:

Diarrhea is not a distinguishing feature of psoriatic arthritis; it is more commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)-related arthritis.

CASPAR Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA):

To classify a patient as having PsA, they must have inflammatory joint disease (affecting joints, spine, or entheses) plus ≥3 of the following 5 criteria:

  1. Evidence of Psoriasis (Any one of the following):
    • Current psoriasis
    • Personal history of psoriasis
    • Family history of psoriasis
  2. Psoriatic nail dystrophy (Option C ruled out)
  3. Negative Rheumatoid Factor (RF)
  4. Dactylitis (Current or past history) (Option B ruled out)
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Enthesitis (Option C): which is inflammation of tendons and ligaments, though not part of CASPAR criteria for PsA, is commonly found in PsA.

 

Note: Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative polyarthritis with erosive arthritis.

questions.text: Identify the type of psoriasis in the given picture.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Guttate psoriasis:

  • A type of psoriasis known as guttate psoriasis is characterized by skin lesions in the shape of small drops. These sores are generally under 1 centimeter in measurement and show up on the storage compartment, appendages, and scalp. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Erythrodermic:  Erythrodermic psoriasis is characterized by widespread skin scaling, inflammation, and redness, frequently accompanied by pain and itchiness.

Option C - Pustular: A form of psoriasis known as pustular psoriasis results in pus-filled blisters on plaques, which are scaly, flaky patches of skin.

Option D - Inverse:  Converse psoriasis. Presents with smooth, red, and inflamed patches of skin that may be itchy, painful, and susceptible to infection are its hallmarks.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with following skin lesions characterized by red and scaly patches. The patient also complains of a painful and swollen finger joint. On examination, the finger joint appears inflamed and tender to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some individuals with psoriasis, a skin condition characterized by red and scaly patches. It often involves joint inflammation, especially in the DIP. The patient's symptoms of red and scaly skin lesions along with painful and swollen finger joints are indicative of psoriatic arthritis. This condition can cause joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, and it is commonly associated with skin manifestations like psoriasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pseudo gout: Pseudo gout is a type of arthritis caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in the joints. It can also lead to joint inflammation and pain, but it typically doesn't have an association with skin lesions like psoriasis. The symptoms described in the case, including the skin lesions, make psoriatic arthritis a more likely diagnosis.

Option C - Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the joints. It is more common in older individuals and typically presents with joint pain and stiffness. However, it does not usually involve the red and scaly skin lesions mentioned in the case.

Option D - Reactive arthritis: Reactive arthritis, also known as Reiter's syndrome, is an inflammatory condition that typically develops as a response to an infection in another part of the body. It often involves joint inflammation, especially in the lower limbs, and can be associated with skin lesions. However, the case description of red and scaly patches on the skin, along with finger joint DIP involvement, is more suggestive of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesion as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pustular psoriasis:

  • Pustular psoriasis is a form of psoriasis characterized by the presence of widespread, sterile pustules on the skin.
  • It can be triggered by the withdrawal of systemic steroids. The fever, malaise, and pustular lesions seen in the image are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Staphylococcal infection: Staphylococcal infections can cause localized or widespread pustules on the skin. However,it does not have the history of steroid treatment

Option C - Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): AGEP is a rare, severe cutaneous reaction characterized by the rapid onset of numerous sterile pustulesHowever, the clinical presentation and history of steroid use in this case are more consistent with pustular psoriasis.

Option D - Subcorneal pustulosis: Subcorneal pustulosist typically presents with localized lesions, and the widespread involvement seen in the image is not characteristic of subcorneal pustulosis.
